source.name: The New York Times

title: How to save a pristine valley
description: How a group of local activists saved the ‘Yosemite of South America’ in the unlikeliest of deals.
content: As the helicopter lifted off and disappeared into the clouds, the roar of the whirring blades fell away and all that was left was the sound of the rain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: 8 Daily Newspapers Sue OpenAI and Microsoft Over A.I.
description: The suit, which accuses the tech companies of copyright infringement, adds to the fight over the online data used to power artificial intelligence.
content: Eight daily newspapers owned by Alden Global Capital sued OpenAI and Microsoft on Tuesday, accusing the tech companies of illegally using news articles to power their A.I. chatbots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: PG&E Seeks Approval to Sell Stake in Its Power Operations
description: California’s largest utility said its proposed deal with the global investment firm KKR could reduce customer rates by $100 million over 20 years.
content: Pacific Gas & Electric announced plans on Tuesday to sell a minority stake in its power-generation business, part of its strategy to reduce electricity rates, continue wildfire prevention and further develop clean energy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: The First Six Weeks of Pregnancy, Explained
description: Florida has banned most abortions after six weeks. Experts explain how that can often be before a woman knows she is pregnant.
content: By the time a woman is considered six weeks pregnant, she would have had two weeks, at most, to realize it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman and Melissa Eddy
title: Europe’s Economic Laggards Have Become Its Leaders
description: More than a decade after painful austerity, Greece, Portugal and Spain have been growing faster than traditional powerhouses like Germany.
content: Something extraordinary is happening to the European economy: Southern nations that nearly broke up the euro currency bloc during the financial crisis in 2012 are growing faster than Germany and other big countries that have long served as the region’s growth engines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kashmir Hill
title: ‘Smartphones on Wheels’ Draw Attention From Regulators
description: Modern cars are internet-connected and have hundreds of sensors. Lawmakers and regulators have concerns about what’s happening with all that data.
content: In the American imagination, car keys and a driver’s license have long represented freedom, autonomy and privacy. But modern cars, which have hundreds of sensors, cameras and internet connectivity, are now potential spying machines acting in ways drivers do not completely understand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: The House That Once Embarrassed Them Is Now a Showplace
description: “Their disdain for this house,” the designer said, “was a green light to give it a whole new life.”
content: For a long time, Alicia and Craig Oberg disliked their house so much that they didn’t want to invite anyone over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: Mali Claims Death of Terrorist Who Helped Lead Deadly Ambush in Niger
description: The West African country said it killed Abu Huzeifa, a commander in an Islamic State affiliate who was involved in a 2017 attack in neighboring Niger that killed American Green Berets and Nigerien forces.
content: Mali said on Monday that it had killed a high-value Islamist commander who helped lead a 2017 attack in which four American and four Nigerien soldiers were killed alongside an interpreter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,046
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jose Quezada, Jonathan Wolfe and Yan Zhuang
title: Police Arrest 25 Protesters at Cal Poly Humboldt, Ending Building Takeover
description: Protesters had occupied an administration building for over a week, leading the university to shut down the campus.
content: Police officers arrested 25 protesters early Tuesday and ended the occupation of an administration building that forced a campus shutdown at California State Polytechnic University, Humboldt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Wants to Prosecute Biden. He Also Thinks Presidents Deserve Immunity.
description: In arguing to the Supreme Court that he cannot be charged for acts while in office, Donald Trump has asked the justices to enforce a norm that he has long threatened to shatter.
content: When a lawyer for former President Donald J. Trump argued before the Supreme Court last week that his client should be immune from charges of plotting to subvert the last election, he asked the justices to picture a world in which former presidents were ceaselessly pursued in the courts by their successors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: College Democrats Back Protests and Criticize Biden’s Israel Policy
description: The student organization of the Democratic Party condemned colleges’ crackdowns on pro-Palestinian protests and called on President Biden to support a permanent cease-fire in Gaza.
content: College Democrats of America, the student organization of the Democratic Party, endorsed pro-Palestinian campus protests on Tuesday and called on President Biden to support a permanent cease-fire in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson and Landon Nordeman
title: Broadway Opened 12 Shows in 9 Days. Here’s What That Looked Like.
description: It’s a challenging time for the theater industry, but as the Tonys deadline approached each new show had reason to pause for a moment and celebrate.
content: Broadway is in the midst of a rolling celebration — of artistic expression, of audience enthusiasm, of song and dance and storytelling itself.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Responses to John McWhorter’s lament that their ubiquity has rendered them meaningless. Also: China and climate; kids’ reactions to news; debate conditions.
content: To the Editor:

title: Getir, a Rapid Grocery-Delivery Service, Exits the U.S. and Europe
description: The company had expanded quickly to keep ahead of rivals, but like other pandemic darlings, its business lost steam after lockdowns were eased.
content: Getir, the rapid grocery-delivery company that boomed during Covid lockdowns, said it was ending its operations in the United States and Europe, a major retreat by another pandemic darling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Water Heaters Use Lots of Energy. The D.O.E. Wants to Change That.
description: The Biden administration is tightening efficiency rules for water heaters, stoves and other appliances, and conservative politicians are dialing up their criticisms.
content: The Biden administration on Tuesday adopted stricter energy-efficiency standards for residential water heaters, the most consequential move in a flurry of changes designed to reduce the energy used by many common appliances including stoves, dishwashers and lightbulbs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Inside an Abortion Clinic Days Before Florida’s Six-Week Ban Takes Effect
description: On one of the last days it would be legal to get an abortion until 15 weeks of pregnancy in Florida, a clinic in Fort Pierce was completely booked.
content: The sky was still dark outside the clinic, but two women were already sitting quietly in the small, beige waiting room while Candace Dye and her staff prepared for an extremely busy morning. It was a few minutes past 5 a.m. on one of the last days it would be legal to get an abortion until 15 weeks of pregnancy in Florida, and A Woman’s World Medical Center in Fort Pierce was completely booked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green, Alexis Soloski and Scott Heller
title: Tony Nominations Snubs and Surprises: Steve Carell and ‘The Wiz’ Miss Out
description: It was a strong year for female directors, a play featuring music and American productions.
content: The day of the Tony Award nominations is like college acceptance day a bit earlier in the spring, but on the scarcity model: Of the dozens of artists eligible in each category, only five or so are “admitted.” That means some great work gets left by the wayside — but also, because the number of nominators is small enough to be idiosyncratic, that plenty of outcomes defy all prediction. Here are our thoughts on this season’s inadvertent (and possibly advertent) snubs, delightful (or mystifying) surprises and other notable anomalies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Meet the Men Who Eat Meat (and Only Meat)
description: With the help of Joe Rogan, a social media trend with staying power emerged from a 2018 book, “The Carnivore Diet.”
content: “Girl dinner” this is not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: Make a Great Taco Even Better With Jackfruit
description: Often amenable in flavor with a texture like pork, the fruit has become a recent favorite among vegetarians.
content: In the middle of the 14th century, on a journey through India, the Florence-born friar Giovanni de’ Marignolli came across a fruit he’d never seen. It was “as big as a great lamb, or a child of 3 years old,” he wrote. “You have to cut it open with a hatchet.” The reward was “a pulp of surpassing flavor, with the sweetness of honey, and” — a pang of homesickness? — “of the best Italian melon.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: Tony Awards Nominations 2024: The Complete List
description: Nominations for the 77th Tony Awards were announced on Tuesday. Here’s who made the list.
content: The Tony Awards nominators didn’t have much time. This year, in a crush of openings, 12 Broadway shows opened in the nine days before the eligibility deadline. (To qualify, a Broadway show must have opened between April 28, 2023, and April 25, 2024.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and John Ismay
title: Deadly Russian Strikes Hit Civilian Center and Other Targets in Odesa
description: Ukraine accused Russia of using a cluster weapon in a civilian area on Monday, killing five people. A strike on Wednesday killed three others, an official said.
content: A Ukrainian official said early Wednesday that a Russian missile attack overnight had killed three people and injured three others in Odesa, a southern Ukrainian city that has been a regular target of Russian missiles and drones trying to destroy its port infrastructure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Rent Board Backs Increases for Millions of New Yorkers
description: The Rent Guidelines Board cast a preliminary vote to back rent increases of between 2 and 4.5 percent on one-year leases across New York City’s one million stabilized apartments.
content: A New York City panel on Tuesday signaled that it would allow rents across nearly one million rent-stabilized apartments to continue to go up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: Three Great Documentaries to Stream
description: This month’s streaming selections include one director’s look at a hometown ritual, the story of an improbable ruse and a celebration of student activism.
content: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll choose three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: Chad Election 2024: What to Know
description: The Central African nation’s May 6 election appears to offer voters a choice. But it’s been masterminded, analysts say, to rubber-stamp the rule of the incumbent, Mahamat Idriss Déby.
content: Chad’s election on May 6 appears to offer voters a choice. But it’s been masterminded, analysts say, to produce a single outcome: to rubber-stamp the rule of the incumbent, Mahamat Idriss Déby, who is seeking to transform himself from military leader to civilian president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Biden Tax Increases Won’t Hit Middle Class, Yellen Says
description: Republicans pressed the Treasury secretary on President Biden’s tax proposals and the fate of the Trump tax cuts that will expire in 2025.
content: The battle lines of the next big tax fight were laid out on Tuesday as Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen sparred with Republicans over the Biden administration’s plans to raise taxes on businesses and wealthy Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: U.S. Rowing Rescinds Ted Nash’s Honors After Abuse Investigation
description: A law firm examining accusations that Ted Nash sexually abused Jennifer Fox — when she was 13 and he was her 40-year-old running coach — found that her claims were credible.
content: A 16-month investigation made public on Tuesday determined that child sexual abuse accusations against Ted Nash, a two-time Olympic medalist and nine-time Olympic coach for the United States who had mythic status in his sport over decades, were credible and that his main accuser had no motive to lie about the abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: In Reversal, Expert Panel Recommends Breast Cancer Screening at 40
description: Some researchers said the advice did not go far enough. The panel also declined to recommend extra scans for women with dense breast tissue.
content: Citing rising breast cancer rates in young women, an expert panel on Tuesday recommended starting regular mammography screening at age 40, reversing longstanding and controversial guidance that most women wait until 50.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed and Melissa Eddy
title: Hydrogen Offers Germany a Chance to Take a Lead in Green Energy
description: A subsidiary of ThyssenKrupp, Germany’s venerable steel producer, is landing major deals for a device that makes the clean-burning gas from water.
content: In the city of Duisburg in Germany’s industrial heartland is a vast steel complex that is one of Europe’s largest polluters. But alongside the mill’s furnaces and smelters, technicians have developed a machine that could soon play a vital role in reducing greenhouse gas emissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: R.F.K. Jr.’s Campaign Says He Will Be on California Ballot
description: The state is the fourth where Mr. Kennedy is all but assured a spot on the ballot in November against President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump.
content: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. will be on the presidential ballot in California, his campaign said Monday, having secured the nomination of the American Independent Party, a minor party with a history of insurgent independent candidacies: Its first presidential nominee, in 1968, was the Alabama governor and segregationist George C. Wallace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: Honeybees Invaded My House, and No One Would Help
description: Responding to fears of a “honeybee collapse,” 30 states have passed laws to protect the pollinators. But when they invaded my house, I learned that the honeybees didn’t need saving.
content: I noticed the first bee one afternoon as my dog gleefully chased it around the house. When the pest settled on a window by the stairwell, I swatted it with a cookbook and cleaned up the mess.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: Women on Bumble No Longer Have to Make the First Move
description: As dissatisfaction with online dating grows, the app that put women in control is shifting course.
content: As the sheen on dating apps dulls, more Americans are reporting bad experiences on them. Frustrated by bots, subscription costs and high effort-to-reward ratios, Gen Z is fleeing the apps in hope of real-life meet-cutes. Earlier this year, “Bustle” declared that dating apps are in their “flop era.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: ‘Staff Meal’ Review: The Last Course for Doomsday Diners and Dates
description: Restaurant patrons and staff members are oblivious to the impending apocalypse in Abe Koogler’s new show at Playwrights Horizons.
content: A woman in the audience started grumbling around 30 minutes into a recent performance of “Staff Meal” at Playwrights Horizons in Manhattan. “What is this play about?” she hissed. A few uncomfortable seconds after she stood up and repeated her gripe for everyone to hear, it was clear that she was part of the show, which opened on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: House Republican Drafts Censure of Omar for ‘Pro-Genocide’ Remark

source.name: The New York Times

title: Killer Asteroid Hunters Spot 27,500 Overlooked Space Rocks

source.name: The New York Times

title: Scenes From the Student Protests Churning Across the Country
description: Despite hundreds of arrests and threats of disciplinary action, pro-Palestinian demonstrations have continued into a third week.
content: Tensions continued to rise at pro-Palestinian student encampments at college campuses nationwide, even as the academic year comes to a close. Some universities are increasing security measures, including deploying police officers to remove demonstrators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: California’s Population Grows for the First Time Since 2020
description: State demographers are optimistic that the population will continue to grow for the foreseeable future.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: N.Y. Criminal Justice Group to Push for More Scrutiny of Judges
description: The group, which led the fight against Gov. Kathy Hochul’s nominee to lead the state’s top court, argues that judges are routinely reappointed to the bench without sufficient evaluation.
content: A group that helped thwart the confirmation of Gov. Kathy Hochul’s choice to lead New York’s highest court last year has announced a campaign aimed at pushing elected officials to more closely scrutinize judicial nominees and appointees across the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wilson Wong
title: A Gripping Family Saga Asks, What Makes for ‘Real Americans’?
description: Rachel Khong’s new novel follows three generations of Chinese Americans as they all fight for self-determination in their own way.
content: As the story goes, after the death of China’s first emperor in 210 B.C., Chen Sheng, a military captain, organized a motley band of soldiers in a revolt against the Qin dynasty and its harsh penal laws. Sheng was defeated, but he became known for his belief that one’s status is not intrinsic — that one can change, grow, transcend. “Are kings, generals and ministers merely born into their kind?” he asked, a rhetorical question that became a rallying cry about identity and self-determination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Are You Screaming for a Free Streaming Choice? Try Shout! TV.
description: Among the free streaming services, few are as enjoyable and reliable as this one.
content: For this month’s spotlight on lesser-known but worthwhile streaming services, we’re showcasing our first advertising-based video-on-demand platform, or A.V.O.D., the model in which services make their money not via subscriptions, but through good old-fashioned advertisements. It’s a trade-off, to be sure; commercials were one of the reasons everyone got rid of cable. But now that Disney+, Netflix and their ilk have shoved ads back into their (paid!) programming, it’s not so hard to tolerate them from a free service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave, Edward Wong, Adam Rasgon and Thomas Fuller
title: Netanyahu Vows to Invade Rafah ‘With or Without’ Cease-Fire Deal
description: As mediators pressed for a truce and Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken toured the region, a ground incursion into the southern Gazan city loomed.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel vowed anew on Tuesday to launch an invasion into the southern Gaza Strip, even as a renewed push for a cease-fire agreement was showing glimmers of a potential breakthrough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oliver Whang
title: From Baby Talk to Baby A.I.
description: Could a better understanding of how infants acquire language help us build smarter A.I. models?
content: We ask a lot of ourselves as babies. Somehow we must grow from sensory blobs into mobile, rational, attentive communicators in just a few years. Here you are, a baby without a vocabulary, in a room cluttered with toys and stuffed animals. You pick up a Lincoln Log and your caretaker tells you, “This is a ‘log.’” Eventually you come to understand that “log” does not refer strictly to this particular brown plastic cylinder or to brown plastic cylinders in general, but to brown plastic cylinders that embody the characteristics of felled, denuded tree parts, which are also, of course, “logs.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan, Glenn Thrush and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Justice Dept. Recommends Easing Restrictions on Marijuana

author: By Gabino Iglesias
title: Alien Terrors, Vampire Conspiracies and More in 4 New Horror Books
description: Our columnist reviews this month’s latest scary releases.
content: If you want to read a novel that feels like a puzzle, look no further than Thomas Olde Heuvelt’s ORACLE (Tor Nightfire, 376 pp., $29.99). The novel, which is translated from the Dutch by Moshe Gilula, opens with two friends, Luca and Emma, who one morning spot a hulking shape in the middle of a flower field. The object is the Oracle, a sailing ship from the 18th century. Curious, Emma goes down the ship’s hatch and vanishes in the darkness beyond. She never comes out. Soon, others — including Luca’s father — and a handful of police officers suffer the same fate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Benjamin Royer

description: University of California, Los Angeles officials had tolerated an encampment for several days but warned Tuesday night that protesters face consequences if they stay.
content: Officials at the University of California, Los Angeles, declared a pro-Palestinian encampment illegal for the first time on Tuesday night and warned protesters that they faced consequences if they did not leave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Columbia Protesters Rename Hamilton Hall to ‘Hind’s Hall’
description: Demonstrators unfurled a banner with the name of a 6-year-old girl who died this year in Gaza during Israel’s war against Hamas.
content: The banner that protesters unfurled at Columbia University’s Hamilton Hall late Monday night read “Hind’s Hall,” a tribute to Hind Rajab, a 6-year-old Palestinian girl who was killed in Israel’s war against Hamas in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Democrats Announce That They Will Rescue Johnson if He Faces Ouster Vote
description: Party leaders said their members would join an effort to table any attempt to remove the Republican speaker after he allowed House passage of military aid to Ukraine.
content: House Democrats said on Tuesday that they would join with the G.O.P. to kill an effort to oust Speaker Mike Johnson if far-right House Republicans forced a vote to remove him from his post after he allowed a foreign aid package including assistance to Ukraine to be approved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ari Berman
title: How Michigan Ended Minority Rule
description: Though the notion would have been laughable a decade ago, Michigan is one promising national model for how state-level activists can retake power.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Bearak and Dionne Searcey
title: Corn to Power Airplanes? Biden Administration Sets a High Bar.
description: Producers of biofuels like ethanol, which could help create a new generation of jet fuel, would have to overhaul their practices to receive tax credits.
content: In a move aimed at lowering the greenhouse gas emissions of air travel, the Biden administration on Tuesday issued new guidelines for how fuel producers — and in particular, makers of ethanol from corn — could qualify for tax credits under a plan to increase the supply of so-called sustainable aviation fuel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenny Holston
title: Inside a Navy Submarine Navigating the Arctic
description: A Times photojournalist embarked on a nuclear-powered attack sub to see how the Pentagon is training for a potential war below the frozen sea.
content: U.S. Navy sailors aboard nuclear-powered submarines have long trained in the Arctic, learning to hunt their Russian counterparts in case of war. But America’s sub force is sharpening its combat skills at the edge of the world as Russia expands military operations there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: All New U.S. Cars Must Carry Automatic Brakes by 2029
description: The technology is already sold on most vehicles, but a new federal safety regulation raises the standards.

title: We Watched Horses Die on the Track. Will Anything Change?
description: Last year, 12 horses died at Churchill Downs, and another 13 died at Saratoga. In a new documentary, two reporters examine the issues surrounding the sport.
content: It was a gorgeous Saturday in August at the storied Saratoga Race Course in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., when Maple Leaf Mel, the undefeated gray filly, came thundering down the homestretch, seemingly on her way to victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: A Proposed Law Targeting ‘Foreign Interests’ in Georgia Riles the Opposition
description: Opponents of the measure, which resembles a Russian law that Moscow has used to crack down on dissidents, say it could undermine efforts for Georgia to join the European Union.
content: For the past month, the Georgian capital of Tbilisi has been engulfed in turmoil. Protesters have taken to the streets of the city night after night. A fistfight broke out between legislators in the country’s Parliament. And over the weekend, there were clashes between police and protesters at a large demonstration in the center of the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Paramount Faces a Mountain of Questions
description: Bob Bakish, the media giant’s chief executive, is out, removing an obstacle to a deal with David Ellison's Skydance. But the company’s future is no clearer as a key deadline approaches.

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: Walmart Introduces a New Store Brand for ‘Quality Food’
description: The Better Goods store brand will carry plant-based, gluten-free and higher-end food and could help the retailer attract more affluent shoppers.
content: When prices for grocery staples surged in 2021 and 2022, some Americans who had not regularly shopped at Walmart increasingly turned to the retailer, which is known for its affordable prices. Now, the company is trying to keep those new customers and attract others with a new selection of plant-based, gluten-free and deluxe culinary fare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Are Bonds Gonna Party Like It’s 1999?
description: Reconsidering my views on interest rates.
content: Do you remember the economy of the late 1990s? Or if you’re too young to remember it — I hope that’s true for at least some of my readers — what have you heard about it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie M. Sheets
title: Princeton University Art Museum Gets Six Site-Specific New Works
description: As the museum’s new building nears completion, shadowed by controversy, artists respond with new commissions.
content: Princeton University has a long history of commissioning public art by the likes of Henry Moore, Louise Nevelson, Alexander Calder and Pablo Picasso, dating back to the 1960s. And when the Princeton University Art Museum opens to the public next year, at almost double the size of its original building, six new large-scale works by women and artists of color will have pride of place — visible beacons near the building’s perimeter, both indoors and out at this central crossroads on campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: Black Entrepreneurs, Frustrated by High Rates, Look to the Election
description: In the battleground state of Georgia, some Black entrepreneurs are frustrated over the impact of higher interest rates, a source of economic anxiety.
content: Kimberly Jolasun, a 32-year-old entrepreneur in Atlanta, has never voted for the Republican candidate for the presidency. That may be about to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Allows, for Now, Texas Law Restricting Access to Porn
description: The law, meant to shield minors from sexual materials on the internet by requiring adults to prove they are 18, was challenged on First Amendment grounds.
content: The Supreme Court refused on Tuesday to block a Texas law that seeks to limit minors’ access to pornography on the internet by requiring age verification measures like the submission of government-issued IDs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Enrique Olvera Heads to Brooklyn With Esse Taco
description: Sammy’s Roumanian Steakhouse returns after an extended Covid closure, Mission Chinese pops up at Cha Kee and more restaurant news.
content: Tacos as street food — if your street is Park Avenue — is Enrique Olvera’s approach at his new Brooklyn spot, his first for the borough; he owns it with Santiago Pérez, the chief executive of Casamata hospitality group. Mr. Olvera, the chef and restaurateur known for Pujol in Mexico City and Cosme and Atla in Manhattan, here offers tortillas made on the premises with heirloom corn stuffed with juicy rib-eye, pork loin and grilled chicken in slices, not chopped up, and smoked oyster mushrooms. Included are salsas and a mix of onions, scallions and cilantro. The standing-only setting has stainless-steel barrels as tables, and the kitchen is open to view. (Opens Thursday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Education Department Scrambles to Make Up for Lost Time After FAFSA Blunders
description: With applications down significantly from past years, officials announced a renewed effort to get students to apply for federal financial aid.
content: The Education Department is trying to make up for lost time after applications for federal financial aid plunged this year, with millions of students navigating delays and glitches caused by the disastrous rollout of the new application form.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Judge Who Brawled With Neighbors Will Remain on N.Y. Bench
description: A state panel voted to censure Mark J. Grisanti, a former Republican state senator, but said he would not be removed for the incident, in which he shoved a police officer.
content: A Buffalo-area judge who brawled with his neighbors and shoved a police officer will be censured but will remain on the bench, a state commission ruled on Tuesday, drawing one of the stranger sagas in New York State judicial history to a close.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Sarah Paulson on Her First Tony Nomination, for ‘Appropriate’
description: The actress, who has portrayed famous public figures and even a pair of conjoined twins, says her current role on Broadway has been the most challenging.
content: After Sarah Paulson moved to New York City when she was a young girl, her mother took a job as a waitress at Sardi’s, a storied Broadway restaurant. It opened up a world that she would not have otherwise been exposed to, helping to nurture her ambitions of performing onstage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Hughes
title: I Let TikTok Tell Me Where to Eat. Here’s What I Learned.
description: A food editor documents the high, the low and the mid from a week’s worth of influencer restaurant suggestions.
content: TikTok is many things: a place for slime videos, a free therapy session, the leading source of information in America right now, and, for some, the ultimate restaurant resource. With a properly tuned algorithm, TikTok can become a never-ending scroll of rhythmic recommendations from critics of varying reliability, many of whom have been paid by restaurants for their P.R.-approved opinions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Robert Jimison
title: After Ukraine Aid Vote, Republicans Braced for Backlash Find Little
description: Some Republicans who backed the aid encountered little resistance from voters, who were far more willing to embrace it — and less interested in ousting the speaker over it — than their right-wing colleagues.
content: A week after he broke with the majority of House Republicans and voted to send $60.8 billion in aid to Ukraine, Representative Max Miller took the stage at a performing arts center in his Ohio district bracing for backlash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Less-Is-More Miso Roasted Salmon
description: Make Eric Kim’s beautifully simple salmon for a classic Japanese breakfast spread or a quick, scrappy dinner.
content: Eric Kim has just written a luminous essay about Japanese breakfast, with its constellation of small savory dishes (rice, miso soup, fish, pickles), and the daily practice of preparing it. You could make it bespoke every day, but the more pragmatic approach is to cook some of the elements ahead and fill out the meal with leftovers and other scraps from the fridge — “cooking for future you, not present you,” as Eric says, an idea I love and one you can embrace for any meal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: What to Know About the Police Shooting in Charlotte
description: Officials said on Tuesday that the man who killed four officers trying to serve arrest warrants on him was armed with a powerful AR-15-style rifle and a 40-caliber handgun.
content: The authorities in Charlotte, N.C., said Tuesday that a man who had opened fire a day earlier on officers trying to serve arrest warrants on him, killing four of them, was armed with a powerful AR-15-style rifle and a 40-caliber handgun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Arizona Rancher Accused of Killing Migrant Won’t Be Retried After Mistrial
description: George Alan Kelly was accused of murdering Gabriel Cuen-Buitimea, an unarmed migrant from Mexico, on his 170-acre ranch in Kino Springs, Ariz., last year.
content: Prosecutors in Arizona said on Monday that they would not retry a rancher who was charged with murdering an unarmed migrant on his property last year after a mistrial was declared last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave and Adam Rasgon
title: Hamas and Fatah Officials, Longtime Rivals, Met in China
description: The Chinese government did not say when the talks between the main Palestinian factions were held. Expectations for progress were low.
content: Officials from Hamas and Fatah, the main Palestinian factions that have long competed for power in Gaza and the West Bank, met in Beijing recently for what Chinese officials on Tuesday called “in-depth and candid talks on promoting intra-Palestinian reconciliation.”
source.name: The New York Times

content: Hamilton Hall, the building at Columbia University that protesters occupied early Tuesday morning, has been occupied several times by student activists over the past half-century.

content: In central Chile, not far from where the Andes Mountains meet the Pacific Ocean, a vast swath of pristine wilderness is changing hands under the most unusual circumstances.

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Are Disposable Hotel Slippers the Next Plastic Straws?
description: Slippers supplied by hotels — flimsy models usually made of plastic and fabric — are the next single-use item in the cross hairs of sustainability activists.
content: In November, managers at the Arenas del Mar resort near Manuel Antonio National Park in Costa Rica, challenged employees to come up with ways to operate more sustainably. The maintenance crew suggested electric locks on guest room doors. The food and beverage department proposed making jams from fruit peels. And the housekeepers advised: Ditch the slippers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: For Trump, a $9,000 rebuke and a stern warning
description: The judge made it clear that further gag-order violations could land the former president in jail.
content: For the entirety of his unorthodox political career, and for decades before in the hype-friendly confines of New York City real estate, Donald Trump’s gift for gab has always been an advantage. Quick with a joke — or a jab — he proved irresistible to innumerable reporters, and millions of voters, who devoured his untrammeled style of slash-and-burn rhetoric.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Coe
title: Maybe Erik Larson Should Have Left the Civil War Alone
description: In “The Demon of Unrest,” present-day political strife inspires a dramatic portrait of the run-up to the deadliest war on American soil.
content: The Civil War is one hell of a drug. It’s plentiful and Main Street-legal, but can induce hallucinatory visions when mixed with inflammatory substances. “I’m so attracted to seeing it,” former President Donald J. Trump confessed at a rally this past Jan. 6, three years after his “Big Lie” inspired followers to storm the Capitol — a feat the Southern Confederacy and its campaign to preserve slavery were unable to accomplish, even as the effort left more than 600,000 people dead in its wake.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Walmart Is Shutting Health Centers After Plan to Expand
description: The 51 locations, next to Supercenters, proved too costly to be profitable, the retailer said.
content: Walmart, the world’s largest retailer, said Tuesday that it was shutting down its health care centers, a network that only last year it said it planned to expand.

description: Changpeng Zhao, the founder and former chief executive of the Binance cryptocurrency exchange, had pleaded guilty to a money-laundering violation.
content: Changpeng Zhao, the billionaire founder of the giant cryptocurrency exchange Binance, was sentenced on Tuesday to four months in prison, a much lighter penalty than other crypto executives have faced since the industry imploded in 2022.

title: Werner Spitz, ‘Medical Detective’ in High-Profile Murders, Dies at 97
description: He figured in the examination of sensational cases involving President John F. Kennedy, Martin Luther King Jr., O.J. Simpson and others.
content: Dr. Werner Spitz, a pathologist whose accounts of the traumatic last moments in some of the most sensational American deaths of the past 60 years figured in cases involving President John F. Kennedy, Martin Luther King Jr., O.J. Simpson, JonBenet Ramsey, Mary Jo Kopechne and many others, died on April 14 in St. Clair Shores, Mich., a suburb of Detroit. He was 97.
